titleStmt.title: M54, 7 of 11. [Anon: distinct from the minstrel, whose words are printed.]. Typescript fragment, 2 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 7 of 11. [Anon: distinct from the minstrel, whose words are printed.]. Typescript fragment, 2 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
distinct from the minstrel (mistrel), whose words are printed.
For when familiar letters (lettres) are written in Biblical prose
there must be a barrier between what is sayable and what
unsayable. There is a limit to what can be put
into words. He cannot talk; he cannot sing. [illeg.] At the beginning
of the sixteenth century (cnstury) he exists; the printing press has
given him a name; but he is still unspecialised.
The man [with?] who stands outside desiring by some impulse to observe (obsev)
, to state, rather than to take part, is not yet wholly
writer, wholly musician or wholly (whllly) painter. It seems possible
that the great English art may (ma) not be the art of words.
He still has the exact observant (observan) eye that sees exactly ; his ear is stimulated
by the sound of words spoken aloud. His words must have body
and substance (substnace), He must make them words sonorous (sornous), since they are to
be read out aloud. I spent most of my time" wrote Lady
"in playing (playin) at Glecko and hearing
read the ....Rivers used to read to me in
Faery Queen
Further (Futher), words must yield (yeild) themselves move easily to the lilt
of the singing voice, to the virginals, to the lute. The
English (Eoglish) were a musical race. For the English were [always?] singing & playing When London was (Londonwas) burning
noted that "hardly one lighter or boat in three
that had the goods of a house in it, but there was a pair
of virginals in it." These were the influences that
told upon the poet; [illeg.] moved Under neath the words: the old words
the new words the [illeg.], the French and (Frechand) the Latin moved the music.
No grammar bound them tightly to gether. They could be read
aloud; danced to and sung to. But they could not follow the

p.sup:
His senses are
attuned then:
he sees within
shadow

div.p:
the pace of the speaking voice. They could not enter into
the private world.

then --"a little man with short hair,
a small band (vband) and cuffs" standing on the threshold of the
"gay and sumptuous house" at , was separate
from Anon the minstrel (misntre); and from the Chronicler;
He was separate too from his audience (adueince). But the book which
had given him his separate (sepatare) existence had brought into being
a little group of readers. That audience began at once to
exert its pressure. What is the book that will please (plase)
my patron What is the theme that will
recommend itself to the ? At once come into existence (ecistence) all
those innumerable (iunnmerable) influences that are to tug and distort and
thwart; as too they are to stimulate and draw out. The
poet is no longer a homeless being a nameless, a wandering voice. He is surrounded [illeg.] with his audience
with an atmosphere (atmopshere). He subjects his inspiration He is played upon by others to outside
influences. Some are visible to himself only; others
only show themselves when time has past. They become more and more complex. A the book goes out into a more and more
numerous, a more and more divided audience.
Some According to its education to its wealth to its poverty (pverty)
the audience begins to demand what it satisfies its own needs
Some need poetry; others history; others a story to make
them forget the drabness of their lives. The thing that
the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered.
